title: Ajax

thumbnail.alt_text: A vertically oriented, dark abstract painting featuring a tall striding figure in white and black lines with nonuniform areas of blue, red, brown, green, gray, and yellow color.

medium_display: Oil on paper, mounted on canvas
publication_history:
Kunsthaus Zurich, Georges Braque, exh. cat. (Zurich: Kunsthaus Zurich, 1953), 1 (ill).

Alexander Liberman, “Braque,” Vogue (October 1, 1954), p. 116 (ill.).

John Richardson, “The Ateliers of Braque,” Burlington Magazine 97:627 (June 1955), p. 164.

Maurice Gieure, G. Braque (New York, 1956), p. 103, pl. 135. 

Catalogue de l’oeuvre de Georges Braque: Peintures 1948–1957 (Paris, 1959), n. p., no. 78 (ill.), as 1954.

John Richardson, Georges Braque (London, 1959), pp. 28 and 32, pl. 32.

John Russell, G. Braque, (New York, 1959), pp. 34 and 126–127, pl. 73.

Jean Leymarie, Braque, trans. James Emmons (Paris, 1961), pp. 112–114 (ill.).

John Richardson, Georges Braque (Greenwich, Conn., 1961), n. p., pl. 60.

Edwin Mullins, The Art of Georges Braque (New York, 1968), pp.129, 189, 196, and 215, pl. 148.

Nadine Pouillon, Braque (Paris, 1970), p. 13 (ill.).

Douglas Cooper, Braque: The Great Years, exh. cat. (Chicago, 1972), p. 105, fig. 83.

Raymond Cogniat, Georges Braque, trans. by I. Mark Paris (New York, 1980), pp. 66 and 158, fig. 68.
exhibition_history:
New York, Museum of Modern Art, The School of Paris: Paintings from the Florene May Schoenborn and Samuel A. Marx Collection, November 1, 1965–January 2, 1966, p. 30 (ill.), as Ajax, 1949-54; traveled to Chicago, Art Institute, February 11–March 27, 1966; St. Louis, City Art Museum, April 27–June 13, 1966; Mexico City, Museo de Arte Moderno, July 2–August 7, 1966; and San Francisco, Museum of Art, September 2–October 2, 1966.

Paris, Grand Palais, Galeries nationales, Georges Braque, 1882–1963, Sept. 16, 2013–Jan. 6 2014; Houston, Museum of Fine Arts, Feb. 16–May 11, 2014.
provenance_text: Aimé Maeght, Paris, after 1954 [Vogue 1954; Worms de Romilly 1959]. Florene May Schoenborn (1903–1995) and Samuel A. Marx (1885–1964), Chicago, from 1955 [New York 1965]; given to the Art Institute, 1997.
